head.title: To Catch a Spy: No Need for a Czar

hedline.hl1: To Catch a Spy: No Need for a Czar

abstract.p: Peter Lifton letter on June 2 article backs Atty Gen Janet Reno's decision to shelve proposal for new counterintelligence czar; holds proposal is effort to deflect attention from rivalries amount United States counterintelligence agencies

block.p: I wholeheartedly agree with Attorney General Janet Reno's decision to shelve a proposal for a new national counterintelligence czar (news article, June 2). Like earlier reorganization plans, this proposal is simply an effort to deflect attention from intense rivalries among United States counterintelligence agencies.

I was the first director for the National Counterintelligence Center's Threat Assessment Office. Before my retirement from the Central Intelligence Agency in 1999, I saw no signs of any genuine trust and cooperation among the four principal United States counterintelligence agencies.

I wholeheartedly agree with Attorney General Janet Reno's decision to shelve a proposal for a new national counterintelligence czar (news article, June 2). Like earlier reorganization plans, this proposal is simply an effort to deflect attention from intense rivalries among United States counterintelligence agencies.

I was the first director for the National Counterintelligence Center's Threat Assessment Office. Before my retirement from the Central Intelligence Agency in 1999, I saw no signs of any genuine trust and cooperation among the four principal United States counterintelligence agencies.

Until interagency rivalries cease, any proposal to reorganize American counterintelligence programs by the executive branch should be viewed as the bureaucratic equivalent of ''rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic.''
